executive_summary: The industry provides services to downstream forestry markets and conducts a range of operations, including resource estimation and mapping, economic analysis, pest control and firefighting. The industry is highly fragmented as the vast majority of companies in the industry are nonemployers contracted on a seasonal basis. Operators in the industry are hired by both government agencies and private companies for forestry support services performed on public and private land. Demand for support services depends on the level of forestry activity in downstream industries and also depends on these markets' propensity to outsource operations to auxiliary companies.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In recent years, the forest support services industry has benefited from growing housing starts, fueled by low interest rates and government stimulus during the COVID-19 pandemic. This led to a surge in demand for lumber as a construction material and associated industry services.

However, as interest rates rose and the supply of sawmill lumber increased, demand for industry services cooled. Despite this, industry revenue has grown at a CAGR of 0.7% to reach $3.5 billion in 2023, although it is set to fall 8.1% due to lower sawmill lumber prices and declining consumer confidence.
The average industry profit margin has fallen to 11.8% of industry revenue in 2023, as lower-margin services like firefighting have gained a larger share of industry revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Downstream demand for lumber from relevant manufacturing and construction is set to remain relatively stable over the coming years.

The price of sawmill lumber is expected to return to steady growth over the coming years, supporting the growth of demand for forest support services revenue in the coming years. Housing starts are set to grow at a CAGR of 1.3% over the five years to 2028, while the price of sawmill lumber is set to rise at a CAGR of 2.2% over the five years to 2028.

Environmental threats to forests, including drought, forest fires and insect infestations, have all been prevalent in recent years and are expected to drive demand for forest support services moving forward. The impacts of climate change will continue to lead to droughts, causing more frequent wildfires. Infestations of disease or insects dry out trees lead to wildfires; forest support services will continue to work to combat these issues.

An increasing provision of firefighting and pest-control services, with decreased provision of timber valuation, forestry research and consultation services, will likely temper growth in industry profit. Firefighting and pest-control services are not as lucrative or value-added as research and consultation services. Nonemployers and smaller operators that largely undertake manual labor, such as thinning and chemically treating timber, are also commonly responsible for firefighting and pest-control services.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry assist downstream timber and logging operators in timber valuation, forestry economics and forest protection. Key support activities include the estimation of timber, forest firefighting, forest pest control and reforestation. Companies may also provide clients with consultation and research services.

negative_impact_factors: low - steady barriers to entry level

key_trends: Price serves as an important basis of competition, since key buying industries seek to minimize input costs where possible. One way forest support service providers attempt to keep prices down is by locating their offices and staff close to forests.

Forestry support service operators fight to obtain a competitive advantage based on level and quality of service. Successful providers navigate this competitive market by securing the more lucrative long-term contracts based on their specializations and experience.
The impacts of climate change have increased demand for forest support services. Industry operators provide services such as firefighting and pest control.
High lumber prices have benefited the forest support services industry. As timber tract operators have earned more, demand for forest support services has rose.
There are no major players in the industry. In 2023, no single industry operator is expected to account for over 5.0% of industry revenue.

A number of federal, state and local agencies influence forestlands in the US. These all impact the forest services industry in turn. There are a number of industry relevant regulations. Some require the setting of standards for the protection of air, water, endangered and threatened species and the use of chemicals as part of forestry operations.

As a service industry, wages are the industry's largest cost. Still, average wage is low due in part to the prevalence of part-time work. Purchases are the industry's second largest cost segment. Purchase costs can vary among operators, with lab services, for example, facing higher purchase costs.

The Southeast is home to the majority of industry operators. The south has an ideal climate for the forestry sector. The West region is home to the second largest share of industry operators. Oregon and Washington are the two states with the most industry operators.
A large portion of US forestland is government-owned. This makes the government a significant market for the forest support services industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Federal, state and county governments all own various parcels of land that are used for a variety of purposes. These include recreation, military activities or for leasing to corporations for forestry and agricultural development. The US government owns an estimated half all forestland in the United States which amounts to an estimated 234.8 million acres. As a result, the government as a direct client constitutes a significant portion of the market for the Forest Support Services industry. Government clients are especially important to driving revenue within the firefighting and pest control service segments.

Accounted for in this segment, timber tract operators are the second-largest purchasers of industry services. Timber tract operators maintain the majority of commercial forests in the United States and are therefore the major purchasers of contract work from the forestry support services sector. With improvements in the housing market and increasing demand for wood, timber tract operators have resumed harvesting timber, which this segment assists with. Timber tract operators often require support services for forest pest control, firefighting and timber estimation.

Logging corporations, who specialize in extracting the trees from the land for the purpose of supplying sawmills with logs, provide an important source of demand for industry services. Some companies own tracts of land and thus contract out various duties, such as research, firefighting and pest control, to industry operators. Logging businesses' share of industry revenue is smaller than that of timber tract operators since the day-to-day management of commercial forests is usually handed to logging businesses by landholders.

products_and_services.product_description: Forest science research is the industry's second-largest service offering and it covers a range of issues, from conservation biology to sustainable forest management and the protection of wildlife and waterways.

The industry provides services relating to forest pest control and firefighting. These are highly practical services offered within the Forest Support Services industry that are primarily performed by specialist companies not engaged in the industry's research aspects.

The industry also provides timber resource estimating and mapping services for clients. These use remote sensing and computerized geographic information systems (GIS) to establish the quantity and quality of timber resources within a particular tract of forestland. Reforestation services also account for a significant portion of industry-related revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Residential construction heavily relies on the availability of lumber and wood products. Therefore, the number of new housing units erected in a given year is positively correlated with demand for timber services and logging operations. In turn, these sectors often require valuation, replanting and other forestry support services, driving industry revenue growth. Housing starts are anticipated to fall in 2023, posing a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The majority of forest support services operators are located in the Southeast region, led by Georgia and Alabama. The Southeast has historically been a major lumber producer given its relatively warm winters and level terrain. As a result of the region's warmer weather, trees are able to grow at a faster rate in this area compared with regions that have colder climates, making the Southeast an attractive destination for industry operators. The Southeast has the highest ratio of private to public forestlands in the country, which is beneficial to operators that derive the majority of demand from private markets.

The West is the second-largest region for forest support services, led by Oregon and Washington, which are the top two states in the nation in terms of industry operators. California accounts for a smaller share of industry establishments. The West has hundreds of millions of acres of forestland. Though this greatly opens the doors for industry operators to conduct business in the region, only a small portion of forestland in the West is privately owned, subduing demand for industry services from private operators.

regulations_points.regulation_description: A highly decentralized and bureaucratic system of government is responsible for forestry policies and their implementation. Over 50.0% of forests in the United States are the responsibility of private owners. The majority of private

regulations_points.regulation_title: Forest Service (FS) and Bureau of Land Management Regulation
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Forest Service (FS) and Bureau of Land Management (BLM) are two key agencies responsible for managing federally owned public forestland and the forestry sector must abide by any management plans put in place by these government agencies. The FS manages the National Forests and Grasslands (8.5% of the nation's land), according to the National Forest Management Act 1976, which requires integrated land and resource management plans be developed. Similarly, the BLM manages federal lands within the context of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act 1976, which establishes regulation of land use between the National Forest System and Indian lands.

As the nation's principal conservation agency, the US Department of the Interior (DOI) is responsible for most of the country's nationally owned resources. The DOI's responsibilities include fostering the most suitable use of the country's land and water resources, protecting the country's fish and wildlife and preserving the environmental and cultural values of national and historic places. The DOI manages the nation's natural resources in the form of setting up national parks, refuges and public lands comprising an estimated 20.0% of the landmass of the United States. It also collects royalties from timber owed to the federal government.

National legislation significantly affects the management of private and public forests, including the Clean Air Act (1970), Clean Water Act (1972), Endangered Species Act (1973) and Toxic Substances Control Act (1976). These laws require the setting of standards for the protection of air, water, endangered and threatened species and the use of chemicals as part of forestry operations. Except for the Endangered Species Act and the Toxic Substances Control Act, states are given much responsibility for developing and enforcing standards specific to local conditions. Other relevant national legislation revised or enacted over the past decade includes the Forest Stewardship Act of 1990, Cooperative Forestry Assistance Act of 1978, America the Beautiful Act of 1990, National Indian Forest Resources and Management Act of 1990 and National Forest-Dependent Rural Communities Economic Diversification Act of 1990.

Sustainable forest management policies, programs and regulations on private forestlands in the United States are governed and implemented under state statutes and authorities. Federal statutes, such as the Clean Water Act, the Endangered Species Act and the Rivers and Harbors Act, can greatly affect private forestlands. A network of state forestry agencies, commissions, extension agents, consulting foresters, landowner assistance programs and others provide resource consulting to landowners to protect water quality or ensure reforestation.

Each state that contains an active forestry sector has enacted laws and regulations to govern the practice of forestry in the state. State laws and regulations can address multiple forest management practices and procedures. Examples include administrative procedures, enforcement and penalties, planning, reforestation water quality, forestry practices, fire, chemical use and forestland conversion.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, which increases barriers to entry.
The industry has a low capital intensity level, decreasing barriers.
The industry receives high and increasing government assistance, decreasing barriers.
The industry has a low concentration level, decreasing barriers.
The industry has a low and steady globalization level, decreasing barriers.

basis_points.basis_description: Price serves as an important basis of competition, as key buying industries seek to minimize input costs.
Providers attempt to keep prices down by locating offices and staff close to forests.
Providers compete based on level and quality of service to secure lucrative long-term contracts.
Successful providers navigate the competitive market by specializing and leveraging experience.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is highly fragmented with most operators being non-employers.
In most cases, it is difficult for operators to generate economies of scale.
The diverse range of services limits consolidation as operators prefer specialization.
Demand for different services is often divided geographically, diluting concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the Second Largest Cost
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The most common purchases include fuel, fire retardants, fertilizers, pesticides and seedlings for replanting. Vehicles for surveying land may also be purchased or leased. For forestry research operators, data and information subscriptions and software purchases are also important.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Forestry support services require heavy investments in labor and capital to operate, creating barriers for new entrants looking to establish a foothold in the industry. Labor costs in particular prove to be cumbersome for operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Forest Support Services Revenue Volatility is Moderate
volatility_points.volatility_description: In recent years, the Forest Support Services industry has exhibited moderate revenue volatility. More landowners are relying on in-house services instead of outsourcing to auxiliary providers such as this industry, resulting in limited industry revenue growth.

In recent years, demand for lumber has risen as demonstrated by a sustained increase in housing starts, driving demand for a range of forest-based services. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and subsequent supply chain issues, the industry has exhibited a marked increase in revenue volatility due to surging prices and demand during the current period as well as an expected deflation of prices and revenue in more recent years.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Drone Technology is Revolutionizing Forest Management
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: - Drones equipped with high-resolution cameras and sensors allow for quick and accurate monitoring of forests, enabling timely identification of invasive species, pests and diseases. - Aerial systems provide detailed information for improved decision-making, ensuring better forest management by regularly assessing tree health, growth rates and timber volumes. - Drone technology reduces the dependence on time-consuming and labor-intensive ground surveys, cutting operational costs and lowering the environmental impact of forest management. - Drones make forest support services more effective and sustainable, with downstream clients attracted to these improving factors.

FAQs.question: How does your company adapt when the levels of residential and nonresidential construction activity diverge?
FAQs.answer: Operators in this industry must be ready for volatile shifts in the housing market as demand for forest support services tie directly back to these key downstream markets. A surging residential housing market during 2020 and 2021 is expected to uplift the demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: Does your company focus on one specific forest support service, or do you provide a range of services?
FAQs.answer: Most operators in this industry are localized with only one person working at the company, as such they generally only provide one service.

FAQs.question: How frequently are you impacted by adverse weather in the region, and how do you manage that risk?
FAQs.answer: Adverse weather conditions, especially forest fires provide increased demand for operators in this industry. Most importantly with the rise incidence of natural disasters as climate conditions deteriorate, it is likely that sensitivity to adverse weather will increase in the future.

FAQs.question: How do you deal with changes in market prices for your inputs?
FAQs.answer: Operators generally try to pass on costs when prices increase, garnering higher revenue but lower profits. When prices fall, the opposite occurs. Furthermore, industry operators may enter into long-term service contracts with downstream customers, protecting themselves from downside risk. However, amid a surge in demand, they could have prevented themselves from incurring larger growth.

FAQs.question: How do you use technology, compared to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: As this industry is highly fragmented, operators use a wide range of technological devices to perform industry services, such as drones.

FAQs.question: Where can you increase your company's level of automation?
FAQs.answer: As most operators in this industry are small with no more than one additional employee, the need for automation is low. Drones can increase labor productivity allowing the employee to cover more ground.

FAQs.question: What agencies are your primary regulators? Have you had any compliance issues in the past?
FAQs.answer: Operators in this industry are regulated by various federal regulators due to the highly fragmented nature of the industry. Two major federal regulators include the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management. The current administration's heightened regulation of the environment and labor safety are likely to increase operating costs.

FAQs.question: Do you receive any federal subsidies? How much do they contribute to your revenue?
FAQs.answer: Most operators do not receive federal subsidies, but the increasingly outsourced firefighting services both from private insurers and the government have increased demand for these services for operators.

FAQs.question: How does your company address seasonal fluctuations in workload?
FAQs.answer: Depending on the service provided, certain companies only operate during certain periods in the year. Larger companies diversify services that they can focus on during different parts of the year.

FAQs.question: How profitable is your company, compared with your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Due to the highly fragmented nature of the industry, profitability ranges based upon the services provided by operators in this industry. By diversifying operations, companies can protect themselves from heightened volatility as well as market risk.

FAQs.question: What incentives do you have in place to maintain a highly skilled workforce? What qualifications must your employees have?
FAQs.answer: Many of the tasks carried out by this industry require highly trained personnel (e.g. remote sensing, timber valuation, consulting and forestry research.)

FAQs.question: How do you ensure the appropriate conditions for growth and harvesting? How do you prepare for uncertain weather conditions?
FAQs.answer: The biophysical conditions of the timber species chosen for growth and harvesting affect operators' ability to gain additional work.

FAQs.question: Do you currently have contacts within key markets? How do you stay ahead of the competition?
FAQs.answer: It is imperative to establish sales through contacts within downstream forestry sectors, given the high level of competition in this industry.

FAQs.question: How do lumber prices affect your business?
FAQs.answer: This industry provides support services to industries that eventually sell sawmill lumber. When timber prices are high downstream operators can better afford industry services. As a result, skyrocketing lumber prices have aided downstream operations.

FAQs.question: How will you pass increased costs down to customers?
FAQs.answer: Operators generally try to pass on costs when prices increase, garnering higher revenue but lower profits.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is spent on fuel?
FAQs.answer: Fuel represents a significant cost for forest support service companies that monitor significant tracts of timberland by ground transportation. Fuel price volatility can have the propensity to ruin margins.

FAQs.question: How will you take advantage of an increase in government consumption and investment? How much of your revenue comes from government entities?
FAQs.answer: Government consumption and investment heavily relies on the firefighting and pest control segments. More importantly, some of the largest timber tracts in the nation are federally owned and therefore represent a significant opportunity for industry operators.
